00-admin/legacy-reports/boost-time.html.title: Boost Time
00-admin/legacy-reports/boost-time.html.description: 831454298542047244 reported that the boost is delayed by a few minutes and doesnt always unlock exactly 24 hours later

01-decision-records-(adrs)/0001-build-po.title: 0001 - Build Portal in Nuxt Stack
01-decision-records-(adrs)/0001-build-po.description:
Supporting evidence
After assessing stacks the new developer is most familiar with, we determined the feature set of NUXT on Nitro with Vite would best serve the long term features of polymart.
We will Build Overhaul in Nuxt Stack.
T3 Stack
Next Stack
Retaining PHP
Positive
• This should result in fastest development time without issues or bugs
Risks & Trade-offs
• Careful consideration will need to be made when choosing how to apply the hybrid rendering system nuxt provides.
Follow-up actions [ ]
01-decision-records-(adrs)/0001-build-po.sourcePath: 01 - Decision Records (ADRs)/0001 - Build Portal in Nuxt Stack.md

01-decision-records-(adrs)/0002-use-post.title: 0002 - Use PostgreSQL
01-decision-records-(adrs)/0002-use-post.description:
Supporting evidence
I considered switching the db from postgres to best fit a serverless api and the new nuxt stack.
We will Use PostgreSQL.
Maria
Firestore
Positive
• All existing data is already on postgres
Risks & Trade-offs
• In order to implement Prisma, or otherwise expand site functionality, we will need to refactor the entire database
Follow-up actions [ ]

01-decision-records-(adrs)/0003-use-pris.title: 0003 - Use Prisma
01-decision-records-(adrs)/0003-use-pris.description: Supporting evidence We noted working with Postgres directly was complex and time consuming, we opted to look at ORM solutions to aid in the development of a datasafe layer to handle all db interactions. We will Add Prisma Layer on top of PostgreSQL.Drizzle https://orm.drizzle.team/ Main site has a lot of negative reviews coming from their own twitter showcase feed. Project looks new and immature. Positive • A proper ORM will make it easier to migrate data in the future, as well as safely interact with the DB now during the development of a new site on existing data. Risks & Trade-offs • Implementing prisma will require a complete refactor of the production database. Follow-up actions Not Applicable

04-due-diligence-kit/if-we-had-unlimited.title: If We Had Unlimited Money
04-due-diligence-kit/if-we-had-unlimited.description:
Note
If someone handed me a blank check tomorrow, this is exactly what I would fix or build in the first 12 months, in priority order. No fluff, no nice-to-haves — these are the highest-ROI changes that would make Polymart dramatically more secure, scalable, and maintainable.
d
04-due-diligence-kit/if-we-had-unlimited.sourcePath: 04 - Due Diligence Kit/If We Had Unlimited Money.md

04-due-diligence-kit/scalability-&-break.title: Scalability & Breaking Points
04-due-diligence-kit/scalability-&-break.description:
Note
These are the exact places Polymart will break or become expensive at the next order-of-magnitude growth. Every bottleneck, single point of failure, and “works until X users” limit is documented here with real numbers from production. This is the infrastructure shopping list for 10×–100× scale.
d

04-due-diligence-kit/security-&-complian.title: Security & Compliance Gaps
04-due-diligence-kit/security-&-complian.description:
Note
Full disclosure of every security, privacy, or compliance gap that exists in Polymart today. These are the items that would fail a formal audit right now. Each line is something I am aware of and have deliberately de-prioritized until we have funding or a larger team. This is the security roadmap in reverse.
d

04-due-diligence-kit/tech-debt-tracker.h.title: Tech Debt Tracker
04-due-diligence-kit/tech-debt-tracker.h.description:
Note
This file is a complete, honest list of every technical corner I consciously cut while building Polymart. Every item here is something I knowingly shipped to move faster, with an estimated severity and rough payback timeline. Nothing is hidden. We can treat this as the exact to-do list whenever developers are idle.
d

info_showCustomIcons.description: Show custom icons for files and folders

info_showDefaultFolderIcons.description: Show a default icon of a folder for every folder in the tree

info_showDefaultFileIcons.description: Show a default icon of a file for every file in the tree

info_defaultFolderIcon.description: The icon to use for folders. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultFileIcon.description: The icon to use for files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultMediaIcon.description: The icon to use for media files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_exposeStartingPath.description: Whether or not to show the current file in the file tree when the page is first loaded

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_sourcePath.description: The local path to the source .html file which will be included.

info_allowFoldingLists.description: Whether or not to allow lists to be folded

info_allowFoldingHeadings.description: Whether or not to allow headings to be folded

info_siteUrl.description: The url that this site will be hosted at

info_authorName.description: The name of the author of the site
